sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.l: Zounds what a question's that?
I tell thee I have more than all you three,
At these ten angels.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.l: I wonder how thou com'st by all this gold,
How many benefices hast thou priest?

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: I'faith but one, dost wonder how I come by gold? I wonder rather how poor soldiers should have gold, for I'll tell thee good fellow, we have every day tithes, offerings, christenings, weddings, burials: and you poor snakes come seldom to a booty. I'll speak a proud word, I have but one parsonage, Wrotham, 'tis better than the bishopric of Rochester, there's ne'er a hill, heath, nor down in all Kent, but 'tis in my parish, Barrham down, Chobham down, Gad's hill, Wrotham hill, black heath, cock's heath, birchen wood, all pay me tithe, gold quoth 'a? ye pass not for that.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Harry ye are out, now parson shake the dice.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Set, set I'll cover ye at all: a plague on't I am out, the devil, and dice, and a wench, who will trust them?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Sayest thou so priest? set fair, at all for once.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Out sir, pay all.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.l: 'Sblood pay me angel gold,
I'll none of your cracked French crowns nor pistolets,
Pay me fair angel gold, as I pay you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No cracked French crowns? I hope to see more cracked French crowns ere long.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Thou meanest of French men's crowns, when the King is in France.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Set round, at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Ihon
sp.p: Pay all: this is some luck.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Give me the dice, 'tis I must shred the priest:
At all sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: The devil and all is yours: at that: 'sdeath, what wasting is this?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Well thrown Harry i'faith.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I'll cast better yet.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Then I'll be hanged. Sirrah, hast thou not given thy soul to the devil for casting?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I pass for all.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.l: Thou passest all that ere I played withal:
Sirrah, dost thou not cog, nor foist, nor slur?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Set parson, set, the dice die in my hand:
When parson, when? what can ye find no more?
Already dry? wast you bragged of your store?

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: All's gone but that.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: What, half a broken angel?

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Why sir, 'tis gold.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yea, and I'll cover it.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: The devil do ye good on't, I am blind, ye have blown me up.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay tarry priest, ye shall not leave us yet,
Do not these pieces fit each other well?

sp.speaker: Sir Ihon
sp.p: What if they do?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thereby begins a tale:
There was a thief, in face much like sir John,
But was not he, that thief was all in green,
Met me last day on black heath, near the park,
with him a woman, I was all alone,
And weaponless, my boy had all my ‚óèoo‚óè‚óès,
And was before providing me a boat:
Short tale to make, sir John, the thief I mean,
Took a just hundreth pound in gold from me.
I stormed at it, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ be revenged
If ere we met, he like a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ,
Broke with his teeth this „Äà‚óä„Äâ ‚óèust in two,
To be a token at our meeting next,
Provided, I should charge no officer
To apprehend him, but at weapon's point
Recover that, and what he had beside.
Well met sir John, betake ye to your tools
By torch light, for master parson you are he
That had my gold.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Zounds I won't in play, in fair square play of the keeper of Eltham park, and that I will maintain with this poor whinyard, be you two honest men to stand and look upon's, and let's alone, and take neither part.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Agreed , I charge ye do not budge a foot, sir John have at ye.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Soldier ware your sconce.

div.stage: Here as they are ready to strike, enter butler and draws his weapon and steps betwixt them.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Hold villains hold, my lords, what do ye mean,
To see a traitor draw against the King?

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: The King! God's will, I am in a proper pickle.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Butler what news? why dost thou trouble us?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Please it your highness, it is break of day,
And as I scouted near to Islington,
The grey eyed morning gave me glimmering,
Of armed men coming down Highgate hill,
Who by their course are coasting hitherward.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Let us withdraw, my lords, prepare our troops,
To charge the rebels, if there be such cause,
For this lewd priest this devilish hypocrite,
that is a thief, a gamester, and what not,
Let him be hanged up for example's sake.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Not so my gracious sovereign, I confess I am a frail man, flesh and blood as other are: but set my imperfections aside, by this light ye have not a taller man ‚ñ™ nor a truer subject to the crown and state, than fit „Äà‚óä„Äâ of Wrotham.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Will a true subject rob his King?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn
sp.p: Alas 'twas ignorance and want, my gracious liege.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: 'Twas want of grace: why, you should be as salt
To season others with good document,
Your lives as lamps to give the people light,
As shepherds, not as wolves to spoil the flock,
Go hang him butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Didst thou not rob me?

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: I must confess I saw some of your gold, but my dread lord, I am in no humour for death, therefore save my life, God will that sinners live; do not you cause me die, once in their lives the best may go astray, and if the world say true, yourself (My liege) have been a thief.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I confess I have,
But I repent and have reclaimed myself.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: So will I do if you will give me time.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Wilt thou? my lords, will you be his sureties?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: That when he robs again, he shall be hanged.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: I ask no more.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And we will grant thee that,
Live and repent, and prove an honest man,
Which when I hear, and safe return from France,
I'll give thee living, till when take thy gold,
But spend it better than at cards or wine,
For better virtues fit that coat of thine.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Vivat rex et currat lex, my liege, if ye have cause of battle, ye shall see sir John of Wrotham bestir himself in your quarrel. Exeunt.

div.stage: After an alarum enter Harry, Suffolk, Huntington, sir John, bringing forth Acton, Beverly, and Murley prisoners.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Bring in those traitors, whose aspiring minds,
Thought to have triumphed in our overthrow,
But now ye see, base villains, what success
Attends ill actions wrongfully attempted.
Sir Roger Acton, thou retain'st the name
Of knight, and shouldst be more discreetly tempered,
Than join with peasants, gentry is divine,
But thou hast made it more than popular.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: Pardon my lord, my conscience urged me to it,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thy conscience? than thy conscience is corrupt,
For in thy conscience thou art bound to us,
And in thy conscience thou shouldst love thy country,
Else what's the difference twixt a christian,
And the uncivil manners of the Turk?

sp.speaker: Beuer.
sp.l: We meant no hurt unto your majesty,
But reformation of religion.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Reform religion? was it that ye sought?
I pray who gave you that authority?
Belike than we do hold the sceptre up,
And sit within the throne but for a cipher,
Time was, good subjects would make known their grief,
And pray amendment, not enforce the same,
Unless their King were tyrant, which I hope
You cannot justly say that Harry is,
What is that other?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: A maltman my lord,
And dwelling in Dunstable as he says.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Sirrah what made you leave your barley broth,
To come in armour thus against your King?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Fie paltry, paltry to and fro, in and out upon occasion, what a world's this? knighthood (My liege) 'twas knighthood brought me hither, they told me I had wealth enough to make my wife a lady.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And so you brought those horses which we saw,
Trapped all in costly furniture, and meant
To wear these spurs when you were knighted once.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: In and out upon occasion I did.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: In and out upon occasion, therefore you shall be hanged, and in the stead of wearing these spurs upon your heels, about your neck they shall bewray your folly to the world.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: In and out upon occasion, that goes hard.

sp.speaker: Mur
sp.p: Fie paltry paltry, to and fro, good my liege a pardon, I am sorry for my fault.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: That comes too late: but tell me, went there none
Beside sir Roger Acton, upon whom
You did depend to be your governor?

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: None none my lord, but sir John Oldcastle.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Bears he part in this conspiracy.Enter Bishop

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: We looked my lord that he would meet us here.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But did he promise you that he would come.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: Such letters we received forth of Kent.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Where is my lord the King? health to your grace,
Examining my lord some of these caitiff rebels,
It is a general voice amongst them all,
That they had never come unto this place,
But to have met their valiant general,
The good lord Cobham as they title him,
Whereby, my lord, your grace may now perceive,
His treason is apparent, which before
He sought to colour by his flattery.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Now by my royalty I would have sworn,
But for his conscience, which I bear withal,
There had not lived a more true hearted subject.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: It is but counterfeit, my gracious lords,
And therefore may it please your majesty,
To set your hand unto this precept here,
By which we'll cause him forthwith to appear,
And answer this by order of the law.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Bishop, not only that, but take commission,
To search, attach, imprison, and condemn,
This most notorious traitor as you please.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: It shall be done, my lord, without delay:
So now I hold lord Cobham in my hand,
That which shall finish thy disdained life.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I think the iron age begins but now,
(Which learned poets have so often taught)
Wherein there is no credit to be given,
To either words, or looks, or solemn oaths,
For if there were, how often hath he sworn,
How gently tuned the music of his tongue,
And with what amiable face beheld he me,
When all, God knows, was but hypocrisy.Enter Cobham.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Long life and prosperous reign unto my lord.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ah villain, canst thou wish prosperity,
Whose heart includeth naught but treachery?
I do arrest thee here myself, false knight,
Of treason capital against the state.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Of treason mighty prince, your grace mistakes,
I hope it is but in the way of mirth.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thy neck shall feel it is in earnest shortly,
Dar'st thou intrude into our presence, knowing
How heinous thou hast offended us?
But this is thy accustomed deceit,
Now thou perceiv'st thy purpose is in vain,
With some excuse or other thou wilt come,
To clear thyself of this rebellion.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Rebellion good my lord, I know of none.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: If you deny it, here is evidence,
See you these men, you never counselled,
Nor offered them assistance in their wars

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Speak sirs, not one but all, I crave no favour,
Have ever I been conversant with you,
Or written letters to encourage you,
Or kindled but the least or smallest part,
Of this your late unnatural rebellion?
Speak for I dare the uttermost you can.

sp.speaker: Mur,
sp.p: In and out upon occasion I know you not.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: No, didst not say that sir John Oldcastle,
Was one with whom you purposed to have met?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.l: True, I did say so, but in what respect?
Because I heard it was reported so.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Was there no other argument but that?

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: To clear my conscience ere I die my lord,
I must confess, we have no other ground
But only rumor, to accuse this lord,
Which now I see was merely fabulous.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The more pernicious you to taint him then,
Whom you knew not was faulty yea or no.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Let this my lord, which I present your grace
Speak for my loyalty, read these articles,
And then give sentence of my life or death.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Earl Cambridge, Scroop, and grey corrupted
With bribes from Charles of France, either to win
My crown from me, or secretly contrive
My death by treason? Is this possible?

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: There is the platform, and their hands, my lord,
Each severally subscribed to the same.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: O never heard of base ingratitude!
Even those I hug within my bosom most,
Are readiest evermore to sting my heart.
Pardon me Cobham, I have done thee wrong,
Hereafter I will live to make amends.
Is then their time of meeting so near hand?
We'll meet with them, but little for their ease,
If God permit: go take these rebels hence,
Let them have martial law: but as for thee,
Friend to thy King and country, still be free. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.l: Be it more or less, what a world is this?
Would I had continued still of the order of knaves,
And never sought knighthood, since it costs
So dear: sir Roger, I may thank you for all.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: Now 'tis too late to have it remedied,
I prithee Murley do not urge me with it.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Will you away, and make no more to do?

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.l: Fie paltry paltry, to and fro, as occasion serves,
If you be so hasty take my place.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: No good sir knight, you shall begin in your hand.

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.p: I could be glad to give my betters place. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bishop, lord Warden, Croamer the shrieve, lady Cob and attendants.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: I tell ye lady, it's not possible
But you should know where he conveys himself,
And you have hid him in some secret place.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My lord, believe me, as I have a soul,
I know not where my lord my husband is.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Go to, go to ye are an heretic,
And will be forced by torture to confess,
If fair means will not serve to make ye tell.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My husband is a noble gentleman,
And need not hide himself for any fact
That ere I heard of, therefore wrong him not.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Your husband is a dangerous schismatic,
Traitor to God, the King, and common wealth,
And therefore master Croamer shrieve of Kent,
I charge you take her to your custody,
And cease the goods of sir John Oldcastle
To the King's use, let her go in no more,
To fetch so much as her apparel out,
There is your warrant from his majesty.

sp.speaker: L. War.
sp.l: Good my lord Bishop pacify your wrath
Against the lady.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Then let her confess
Where Oldcastle her husband is concealed.

sp.speaker: L. warden
sp.l: I dare engage mine honour and my life,
Poor gentlewoman, she is ignorant,
And innocent of all his practises,
If any evil by him be practised.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: If my lord warden? nay then I charge you,
that all the cinque ports whereof you are chief
Be laid forthwith, that he escape us not,
Show him his highness' warrant m. Shrieve.

sp.speaker: L. warden
sp.p: I am sorry for the noble gentleman,Enter Oldcastle and Harp.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: Peace, he comes here, now do your office.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle
sp.l: Harpoole what business have we here in hand?
What makes the Bishop and the sheriff here,
I fear my coming home is dangerous,
I would I had not made such haste to Cobham.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Be of good cheer my lord, if they be foes we'll scramble shrewdly with them, if they be friends they are welcome: one of them (My lord, warden) is your friend, but methinks my lady weeps, I like not that.

sp.speaker: Croo.
sp.p: Sir John Oldcastle lord Cobham, in the King's majesty's name, I arrest ye of high treason.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.p: Treason m. Croomes?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Treason m. Shrieve, 'sblood what treason?

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Harpoole I charge thee stir not, but be quiet still,
Do ye arrest me m. Shrieve for treason?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: Yea of high treason, traitor, heretic.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Defiance in his face that calls me so,
I am as true a loyal gentleman
Unto his highness, as my proudest enemy,
The King shall witness my late faithful service,
For safety of his sacred majesty.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: What thou art, the King's hand shall testify,
Show't him lord warden.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Jesu defend me,
Is't possible your cunning could so temper
The princely disposition of his mind,
To sign the damage of a royal subject?
Well, the best is, it bears an antedate,
Procured by my absence, and your malice,
But I, since that, have showed myself as true,
As any churchman that dare challenge me,
Let me be brought before his majesty,
if he acquit me not, then do your worst.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: We are not bound to do kind offices
For any traitor, schismatic, nor heretic,
The King's hand is our warrant for our work,
Who is departed on his way for France,
And at Southampton doth repose this night.

sp.speaker: Harp
sp.p: O that it were the blessed will of God, that thou and I were within twenty mile of it, on Salisbury plain! I would lose my head if ever thou broughtest thy head hither again.Aside.

sp.speaker: Old‚óèa.
sp.p: My lord warden o'th cinque ports, and my lord of Rochester, ye are joint commissioners, favour me so much, on my expense to bring me to the King.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: What, to Southampton?

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Thither my god lord,
And if he do not clear me of all guilt,
And all suspicion of conspiracy,
Pawning his princely warrant for my truth:
I ask no favour, but extremest torture.
Bring me, or send me to him, good my lord,
Good my lord warden, m shrieve, entreat.
sp.stage: Here the lord warden, and Cromer uncover to the Bishop, and secretly whispers with him.
sp.l: Come hither lady, nay, sweet wife forbear,
To heap one sorrow on another's neck,
'Tis grief enough falsely to be accused,
And not permitted to acquit myself,
Do not thou with thy kind respective tears,
Torment thy husband's heart that bleeds for thee,
But be of comfort, God hath help in store,
For those that put assured trust in him.
Dear wife, if they commit me to the tower,
Come up to London to your sister's house:
That being near me, you may comfort me.
One solace find I settled in my soul,
That I am free from treasons very thought,
only my conscience for the gospels sake,
Is cause of all the troubles I sustain.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O my dear lord, what shall betide of us?
You to the tower, and I turned out of doors,
Our substance ceased unto his highness use,
Even to the garments longing to our backs.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Patience good madam, things at worst will mend,
And if they do not, yet our lives may end.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Urge it no more, for if an angel spoke,
I swear by sweet saint Peter's blessed keys,
First goes he to the tower, then to the stake.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: But by your leave, this warrant doth not stretch
To imprison her.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: No, turn her out of doors,L. warden and Oldcastle whisper.
Even as she is, and lead him to the tower,
With guard enough for fear of rescuing.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O God requite thee thou bloodthirsty man.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: May it not be my lord of Rochester?
Wherein have I incurred your hate so far,
That my appeal unto the king's denied?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: No hate of mine, but power of holy church,
Forbids all favour to false heretics.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Your private malice more than public power,
Strikes most at me, but with my life it ends.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: O that I had the Bishop in that fear,Aside
That once I had his sumner by ourselves.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: My lord yet grant one suit unto us all,
That this same ancient serving man may wait
Upon my lord his master in the tower.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: This old iniquity, this heretic?
That in contempt of our church discipline,
Compelled my sumner to devour his processet
Old ruffian past-grace, up start schismatic,
Had not the King prayed us to pardon ye,
Ye had fried for it, ye grizild heretic.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p:
'Sblood my lord Bishop, ye do me wrong, I am neither
heretic nor Puritan, but of the old church, I'll swear, drink ale, kiss a wench, go to mass, eat fish all lent, and fast Friday's with cakes and wine, fruit and spicery, shrive me of my old sins afore easter, and begin new afore Whitsuntide.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: A merry mad conceited knave my lord.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: That knave was simply put upon the Bishop.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Well, God forgive him and I pardon him.
Let him attend his master in the tower,
For I in charity wish his soul no hurt.

sp.speaker: Oldca
sp.p: God bless my soul from such cold charity,

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Tooth tower with him, and when my leisure serves,
I will examine him of articles,
Look my lord warden as you have in charge,
The shrieve perform his office.

sp.speaker: L. Ward.
sp.p: Yes my lord. Enter the sumner with books.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: What bringst thou there? what? books of heresy.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Yea my lord, here's not a Latin book,
No not so much as our lady's psalter,
Here's the bible, the testament the psalms in meeter,
The sickman's salve, the treasure of gladness,
And all in English, not so much but the almanac's English.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Away with them, to'th fire with them Clun,
Now fie upon these upstart heretics,
All English, burn them, burn them quickly Clun.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: But do not Sumner as voule answer it, for I have there English books my lord, that I'll not part with for your bishopric, Bevis of Hampton, owlglass, the friar and the boy, Ellen of Rumming, Robin hood, and other such godly storeys which if ye burn, by this flesh I'll make ye drink their ashes in s. Marget's ale.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the Bishop of Rochester with his men, in livery coats.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: Is it your honour's pleasure we shall stay,
Or come back in the afternoon to fetch you.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Now you have brought me here into the tower,
You may go back unto the porter's lodge,
And send for drink or such things as you want,
Where if I have occasion to employ you,
I'll send some officer to call you to me.
Into the city go not, I command you,
Perhaps I may have present need to use you.

sp.p: We will attend your worship here without.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: Do so I pray you.
Come, we may have a quart of wine at the rose at barking, I warrant you, and come back an hour before he be ready to go.
We must hie us then.
Let's away.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: Ho, m. lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Who calls there?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: A friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: My lord of Rochester, your honour's welcome.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Sir here's my warrant from the counsel,
For conference with sir John Oldcastle,
Upon some matter of great consequence.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Ho, sir John.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Who calls there?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Harpoole, tell sir John, that my lord of Rochester comes from the counsel to confer with him.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I think you may as safe without suspicion,
As any man in England as I hear,
For it was you most laboured his commitment.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: I did sir, and nothing repent it I assure you.
M. lieutenant I pray you give us leave,
I must confer here with sir John a little.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: With all my heart my lord.

sp.speaker: Harp aside.
sp.p: My lord be ruled by me, take this occasion while 'tis offered, and on my life your lordship shall escape.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.p: No more I say, peace lest he should suspect it.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: Sir John I am come unto you from the lords of his highness most honourable counsel, to know if yet you do recant your errors, conforming you unto the holy church.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.l: My lord of Rochester on good advice,
I see my error, but yet understand me,
I mean not error in the faith I hold,
But error in submitting to your pleasure,
Therefore your lordship without more to do.
Must be a means to help me to escape.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: What means? thou heretic?
Dar'st thou but lift thy hand against my calling?

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: No not to hurt yond for a thousand pound,

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Nothing but to borrow your upper garments a little; not a word more, for if you do, you die: peace, for waking the children, there, put them on, dispatch, my lord, the window that goes out into the leads, is sure enough, I told you that before, there, make you ready, I'll convey him after, and bind him surely in the inner room.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.l: This is well begun, God send us happy speed,
Hard shift you see men make in time of need: Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Here my lord, come come away.

div.stage: Enter serving men again.

sp.p: I marvel that my lord should stay so long.
He hath sent to seek us, I dare lay my life.
We come in good time, see where he is coming.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: I beseech you good my lord of Rochester, be favourable to my lord and master.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.l: The inner rooms be very hot and close,
I do not like this air here in the tower.

sp.speaker: Harp
sp.p: His case is hard my lord, you shall safely get out of the tower, but I will down upon them, in which time get you away.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.p: Fellow thou troublest me.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p:
Hear me my lord, hard under Islington wait you my coming, I will bring my lady ready, with horses
to convey you hence.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.p: Fellow, go back again unto thy lord and counsel him.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Nay my good lord of Rochester, I'll bring you to s. Albons through the woods, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.p: Villain away.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Nay since I am passed the tower's liberty, thou partest not so.Be draws.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: Clubs clubs, clubs.
Murder, murder murder.
Down with him.They fight.
A villain traitor.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: You cowardly rogues.Sir John escapes.

div.stage: Enter lieutenant and his men.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Who is so bold as dare to draw a sword,
So near unto the entrance of the tower?

sp.p: This ruffian servant to sir John Oldcastle was like to have slain my lord.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Stand off if you love your puddings.

div.stage: Rochester calls within.

sp.speaker: Rock
sp.p: Help help, help, m. lieutenant help.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Who's that within? some treason in the tower upon my life, look in, who's that which calls?Enter Roch. bound.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Without your cloak my lord of Rochester?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: There, now it works, then let me speed, for now is the fittest time for me to scape away.Exit

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Why do you look so ghastly and affrighted?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Oldcastle that traitor and his man,
When you had left me to confer with him,
Took, bound, and stripped me, as you see,
And left me lying in his inner chamber,
And so departed, and I

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: And you! never say that the lord Cobham's man
Did here set upon you like to murder you.

sp.p: And so he did.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: It was upon his master than he did,
That in the brawl the traitor might escape.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Where is this Harpoole?
Here he was even now.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Where can you tell? they are both escaped,
Since it so happens that he is escaped,
I am glad you are a witness of the same,
It might have else been laid unto my charge,
That I had been consenting to the fact.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Come, search shall be made for him with expedition, the havens laid that he shall not escape, and hue and cry continue through England, to find this damned dangerous heretic.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Cambridge, Scroop, and Gray, as in a chamber, and set down at a table, consulting about their treason: King Harry and Suffolk listening at the door.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: In mine opinion, Scroop hath well advised,
Poison will be the only aptest mean,
And fittest for our purpose to dispatch him.

sp.speaker: Grey
sp.l: But yet there may be doubt in their delivery,
Harry is wise, therefore Earl of Cambridge,
I judge that way not so convenient.

sp.speaker: Scroop
sp.l: What think ye then of this? I am his bedfellow,
And unsuspected nightly sleep with him.
What if I venture in those silent hours,
When sleep hath sealed up all mortal eyes,
To murder him in bed? how like ye that?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Herein consists no safety for yourself,
And you disclosed, what shall become of us?
But this day (As ye know) he will aboard,
The wind so fair, and set away for France,
If as he goes, or entering in the ship,
It might be done, than it were excellent,

sp.speaker: Grey
sp.l: Why any of these, or if you will,
I'll cause a present sitting of the council,
Wherein I will pretend some matter of such weight,
as needs must have his royal company,
And to dispatch him in the council chamber.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Tush, yet I hear not any thing to purpose,
I wonder that lord Cobham stays so long,
His counsel in this case would much avail us.

div.stage: They rise from the table, and the King steps in to them with his lords.

sp.speaker: Scroop
sp.p: What shall we rise thus, and determine nothing?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: That were a shame indeed, no, sit again,
And you shall have my counsel in this case,
If you can find no way to kill this King,
Than you shall see how I can further ye,
Scroope's way by poison was indifferent,
But yet being bedfellow unto the King,
And unsuspected sleeping in his bosom,
In mine opinion, that's the likelier way,
For such false friends are able to do much,
And silent night is treason's fittest friend,
Now, Cambridge in his setting hence for France,
Or by the way, or as he goes aboard,
To do the deed, that was indifferent too,
Yet somewhat doubtful; might I speak my mind,
For many reasons needless now to urge.
Marry lord grey came something near the point,
To have the King at council, and there murder him,
As Caesar was amongst his dearest friends:
None like to that, if all were of his mind.
Tell me o tell me you bright honours stains,
For which of all my kindnesses to you,
Are ye become thus traitors to your King?
And France must have the spoil of Harry's life?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O pardon us dread lord.All kneeling.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: How pardon ye? That were a sin indeed,
Drag them to death, which justly they deserve,They lead them away.
And France shall dear buy this villainy,
So soon as we set footing on her breast,
God have the praise for our deliverance,
And next, our thanks (Lord Cobham) is to thee,
True perfect mirror of nobility.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the host, sir John Oldcastle, and Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Sir, you are welcome to this house, to such as here is with all my heart, but by the mass I fear your lodging will be the worst, l have but two beds, and they are both in a chamber, and the carrier and his daughter lies in the one, and you and your wife must lie in the other.

sp.speaker: L. Cobh.
sp.l: In faith sir, for myself I do not greatly pass,
My wife is weary, and would be at rest,
For we have travelled very far today,
We must be content with such as you have.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: But I cannot tell how to do with your man.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: What, hast thou never an empty room in thy house for me?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Not a-bed by my troth: there came a poor Irish man, and I lodged him in the barn, where he has fair straw, though he have nothing else.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Well mine host, I pray thee help me to a pair of fair sheets, and I'll go lodge with him.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: By the mass that thou shalt, a good pair of hempen sheets, were never lain in: come.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter constable, Maior, and watch.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: What have you searched the town?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: All the town sir, we have not left a house unsearched that uses to lodge.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.l: Surely my lord of Rochester was then deceived,
Or ill informed of sir John Oldcastle,
Or if he came this way, he's passed the town,
He could not else have scaped you in the search.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: The privy watch hath been abroad all night,
And not a stranger lodgeth in the town
But he is known, only a lusty priest
We found in bed with a pretty wench,
that says she is his wife, yonder at the shears:
But we have charged the host with his forth coming
To morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: What think you best to do?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Faith master mayor, here's a few straggling houses beyond the bridge, and a little inn where carriers use to lodge, though I think surely he would ne'er lodge there: but we'll go search, and the rather, because there came notice to the town the last night of an Irish man, that had done a murder, whom we are to make search for.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: Come I pray you, and be circumspect.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: First beset the house, before you begin the search.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Content, every man take a several place.
sp.stage: Here is heard a great noise within.
sp.l: Keep, keep, strike him down there, down with him.

div.stage: Enter constable with the Irish man in harpooles apparel.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Come you villainous heretic, confess where your master is.

sp.speaker: Irish man
sp.p: Vat mester?

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: Vat mester, you counterfeit rebel, this shall not serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Irish man
sp.p: Be sent Patrick I ha' no mester.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Where's the lord Cobham sir John Oldcastle that lately is escaped out of the tower.

sp.speaker: Irish man
sp.p: Vat lort Cobham?

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: You counterfeit, this shall not serve you, we'll torture you, we'll make you to confess where that arch-heretic lord Cobham is: come bind him fast.

sp.speaker: Irish man
sp.p: Ahone, ahone, ahone, a c‚óèee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Ahone, you crafty rascal?Exeunt.

div.stage: Lord Cobham comes out in his gown stealing.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Harpoole, Harpoole, I hear a marvelous noise about the house, God warrant us, I fear we are pursued: what Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Who calls there?

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: 'Tis I, dost thou not hear a noise about the house?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Yes marry do I, zounds, I can not find my hose, this Irish rascal that was lodged with me all night, hath stolen my apparel, and has left me nothing but a lousy mantle, and a pair of broags. Get up, get up, and if the carrier and his wench be asleep, change you with them as he hath done with me, and see if we can escape.

div.stage: A noise again heard about the house, a pretty while, then enter the constable meeting Harpoole in the Irish man's apparel.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Stand close, here comes the Irish man that did the murder, by all tokens, this is he.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: And perceiving the house beset, would get away: stand sirrah.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: What art thou that bidst me stand?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I am the officer, and am come to search for an Irish man, such a villain as thyself, that hast murdered a man this last night by the high way.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: 'Sblood constable, art thou mad? am I an Irish man?

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: Sirrah, we'll find you an Irish man before we part: lay hold upon him.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Make him fast: oh thou bloody rogue!

div.stage: Enter lord Cobham and his lady in the carrier and wench's apparel.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: What will these ostlers sleep all day?
Good morrow, good morrow, come wench, come,
Saddle, saddle, now afore God too foord-dayes, ha?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Who comes there?

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: O 'tis Lancashire carrier, let him pass.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: What, will nobody open the gates here?
Come, let's in't stable to look to our capons.

div.stage: The carrier calling.

sp.speaker: Club calling
sp.p: Host, why ostler, zwookes, here's such abomination company of boys: a pox of this pigsty at the house end, it fills all the house full of fleas, ostler, ostler.

sp.speaker: Ostler
sp.p: Who calls there, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Zwookes, do you rob your guests? do you lodge rogues and slaves, and scoundrels, ha? they ha' stolen our doths here: why ostler?

sp.speaker: Ostler
sp.p: A murrain choke you, what a bawling you keep.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: How now, what would the carrier have? look up there.

sp.speaker: Ostler
sp.p: They say that the man and woman that lay by them have stolen their clothes.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: What, are the strange folks up yet that came in yesternight ?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What mine host, up so early?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: What, master maior, and master constable!

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: We are come to seek for some suspected persons, and such as here we found, have apprehended.

div.stage: Enter the carrier and Kate in lord Cobham and ladies apparel.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Who comes here?

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Who comes here? A plague found ome, you bawl quoth 'a, ods hat, I'll forzweare your house, you lodged a fellow and his wife by us that ha' run away with our 'parel, and lefted us such gewgaws here, come Kate, come to me, thowse dizeard i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: Mine host, know you this man?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Yes master maior, I'll give my word for him, why neighbour club, how comes this gear about?

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: Now a foul on't, I can not make this gewgaw stand on my head, now the lads and the lasses won flout me too too

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: How came this man and woman thus attired?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Here came a man and woman hither this last night, which I did take for substantial people, and lodged all in one chamber by these folks: methinks , have been so bold to change apparel, and gone away this morning ere they rose.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: That was that villain traitor Oldcastle, that thus escaped us: make out hue and cry yet after him, keep fast that traitorous rebel his servant there: farewell mine host.

sp.speaker: Carier
sp.p: Come Kate Owdham, thou and Ise trimly dizzard.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p:
i'faith neame club, Ise wot never what to do, Ise be so
flouted and so shouted at: but by th' mess Ise cry. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter priest and Doll.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.l: Come Dol, come, be merry wench,
Farewell Kent, we are not for thee,
Be lusty my lass, come for Lancashire,
We must nip the boung for these crowns.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Why is all the gold spent already that you had the other day?

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Gone doll, gone, flown, spent, vanished, the devil, drink and the dice, has devoured all.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: You might have left me in Kent, that you might, until you had been better provided, I could have stayed at Cobham.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: No Dol, no, I'll none of that, kent's too hot doll, kent's too hot: the weathercock of Wrotham will crow no longer, we have plucked him, he has lost his feathers, I have pruned him bare, left him thrice, is moulted, is moulted, wench.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Faith sir John, I might have gone to service again, old master Harpoole told me he would provide me a mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Peace Doll, peace, come mad wench, I'll make thee an honest woman, we'll into Lancashire to our friends, the troth is, I'll marry thee, we want but a little money to buy us a horse, and to spend by the way, the next sheep that comes shall lose his fleece, we'll have these crowns wench I warrant thee: stay, who comes here? some Irish villain methinks thatEnter the Irish man with his master slain.has slain a man, and draws him out of the way to rifle him: stand close doll, we'll see the end. The Irish man falls to rifle his master.alas poe mester, s. Rishard Lee, be saint Patrick is rob and cut thy troth, for dee shame, and die money, and d'ye gold ring, be me truly is love thee well, but now dow be kil thee, be shitten knave.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Stand sirrah, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Irishman.
sp.p: Be saint Patrick mester is poor Irisman, is a leufter.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p:
Sirrah, sirrah, you are a damned rogue, you have killed a man here, and rifled him of all that he has, 'sblood you
rogue deliver, or I'll not leave you so much as an Irish hair above your shoulders, you whoreson Irish dog, sirrah untruss presently, come off and dispatch, or by this cross I'll fetch your head off as clean as a bark.

sp.speaker: Irishman.
sp.p: Wees me saint Patrick, Ise kill me mester for chain and his ring, and nows be rob of all, mees undo.

div.stage: Priest robs him.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: Avant you rascal, go sirrah, be walking, come Doll the devil laughs, when one thief robs another, come mad wench, we'll to saint Albons, and revel in our bower, heigh my brave girl.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: O thou art old sir John, when all's done i'faith.

div.stage: Enter the host of the bell with the Irish man.

sp.speaker: Irishman
sp.p: Be me trow mester is poor Irisman, is want judging, is have no money, is starve and cold, good mester give her some meat, is famise and tie.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: I'faith my fellow I have no lodging, but what I keep for my guess, that I may not disappoint, as for meat thou shalt have such as there is, and if thou wilt lie in the barn, there's fair straw, and room enough.

sp.speaker: Irishman
sp.p: Is thanke my mester heartily, de straw is good bed for me.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Ho Robin?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Show this poor Irishman into the barn, go sirrah.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter carrier and Kate.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Ho, who's within here, who looks to the horses? God's hat here's fine work, the hens in the manger, and the hogs in the litter, a bot's found you all, here's a house well looked too yvaith.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: Mass goffe club, Ise very cawd.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Get in Kate, get in to fire and warm thee.

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Ho John ostler.

sp.speaker: Hostler
sp.l: What gaffer club, welcome to saint Albons,
How does all our friends in Lancashire?

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Well God have mercy John, how does Tom, where's he?

sp.speaker: Hostler
sp.p: O Tom is gone from hence, he's at the three horse-loves at Stony-stratford, how does old Dick Dunne?

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: God's hat old Dunne has been mired in a slough in Brickhill-lane, a plague found it, yonder is such abomination weather as never was seen.

sp.speaker: Hostler.
sp.p: God's hat thief, have one half peck of pease and oats more for that, as I am John ostler, he has been ever as good a jade as ever travelled.

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Faith well said old Jack, thou art the old lad still.

sp.speaker: Hostler
sp.p: Come gaffer club, unload, unload, and get to supper, and I'll rub dun the while. Come.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir John Oldcastle, and his lady disguised.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Come madam, happily escaped, here let us sit,
This place is far remote from any path,
And here awhile our weary limbs may rest,
To take refreshing, free from the pursuit
Of envious Winchester.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: But where (My lord,)
Shall we find rest for our disquiet minds?
There dwell untamed thoughts that hardly stoop,
To such abasement of disdained rags,
We were not wont to travel thus by night,
Especially on foot.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: No matter love,
Extremities admit no better choice,
And were it not for thee, say froward time,
Imposed a greater task, I would esteem it
As lightly as the wind that blows upon us,
But in thy sufferance I am doubly tasked,
Thou wast not wont to have the earth thy stool,
Nor the moist dewy grass thy pillow, nor
Thy chamber to be the wide horizon,

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How can it seem a trouble, having you
A partner with me, in the worst I feel?
No gentle lord, your presence would give ease
To death itself, should he now seize upon me,
Behold what my foresight hath undertakenHeres bread and cheese and a bottle.
For fear we faint, they are but homely cates.
Yet sauced with hunger, they may seem as sweet,
As greater dainties we were wont to taste.

sp.speaker: Old‚óèa.
sp.l: Praise be to him whose plenty sends both this,
And all things else our mortal bodies need,
Nor scorn we this poor feeding, nor the state
We now are in, for what is it on earth,
Nay under heaven, continues at a stay?
Ebbs not the sea, when it hath overflown?
Flows not darkness when the day is gone?
And see we not sometime the eye of heaven,
Dimmed with overflying clouds: there's not that work
Of careful nature, or of cunning art,
(How strong, how beauteous, or how rich it be)
But falls in time to ruin: here gentle madam,
In this one draught I wash my sorrow down.Drinks.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And I encouraged with your cheerful speech,
Will do the like.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Pray God poor Harpoole come,
If he should fall into the Bishop's hands,
Or not remember where we bade him meet us,
It were the thing of all things else, that now
Could breed revolt in this new peace of mind.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Fear not my lord, he's witty to devise,
And strong to execute a present shift.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: That power be still his guide hath guided us,
My drowsy eyes wax heavy, early rising,
Together with the travel we have had,
Make me that I could gladly take a nap,
Were I persuaded we might be secure.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Let that depend on me, whilst you do sleep,
I'll watch that no misfortune happen us,
Lay then your head upon my lap sweet lord,
and boldly take your rest.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: I shall dear wife,
Be too much trouble to thee.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Urge not that,
My duty binds me, and your love commands.
I would I had the skill with tuned voice,
To draw on sleep with some sweet melody,
But imperfection and unaptness too,
Are both repugnant, fear inserts the one,
The other nature hath denied me use.
But what talk I of means to purchase that,
Is freely happened? sleep with gentle hand,
Hath shut his eyelids, o victorious labour,
How soon thy power can charm the body's sense?
And now thou likewise climb'st unto my brain,
Making my heavy temples stoop to thee,
Great God of heaven from danger keep us free.Both sleeps.

div.stage: Enter sir Richard Lee, and his men

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: A murder closely done and in my ground?
Search carefully, if anywhere it were,
This obscure thicket is the likeliest place.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Sir I have found the body stiff with cold,
And mangled cruelly with many wounds.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: Look if thou knowest him, turn his body up,
A lack it is my son, my son and heir,
Whom two years since, I sent to Ireland,
To practise there the discipline of war,
And coming home (For so he wrote to me)
Some savage heart, some bloody devilish hand,
Either in hate, or thirsting for his coin,
Hath here sluiced out his blood, unhappy hour,
Accursed place, but most inconstant fate,
That hadst reserved him from the bullets fire,
And suffered him to scape the wood-kern fury,
Didst here ordain the treasure of his life,
(Even here within the arms of tender peace,
and where security gate greatest hope)
To be consumed by treasons wasteful hand?
And what is most afflicting to my soul,
That this his death and murder should be wrought,
Without the knowledge by whose means 'twas done,

sp.speaker: 2 servants
sp.l: Not so sir, I have found the authors of it,
See where they sit, and in their bloody fists,
The fatal instruments of death and sin.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: Just judgement of that power, whose gracious eye,
Loathing the sight of such a heinous fact,
Dazzled their senses with benumbing-sleep,
Till their unhallowed treachery were known:
Awake ye monsters, murderers awake,
Tremble for horror, blush you cannot choose,
Beholding this inhumane deed of yours.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: What mean you sir to trouble weary souls,
And interrupt us of our quiet sleep?

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: O devilish! can you boast unto yourselves
Of quiet sleep, having within your hearts
The guilt of murder waking, that with cries
Deafs the loud thunder, and solicits heaven,
With more than mandrake's shrieks for your offence?

sp.speaker: Lady Old.
sp.p: What murder? you upbraid us wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: Can you deny the fact? see you not here,
The body of my son by you misdone?
Look on his wounds, look on his purple hue:
Do we not find you where the deed was done?
Were not your knives fast closed in your hands?
Is not this cloth an argument beside,
Thus stained and spotted with his innocent blood?
These speaking characters, were nothing else
To plead against ye, would convict you both.
Bring them away, bereavers of my joy,
At Hartford where the sises now are kept,
Their lives shall answer for my son's lost life.

sp.speaker: Old castle
sp.p: As we are innocent, so may we speed.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.p: As I am wronged, so may the law proceed.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bishop of Rochester, constable of s. Albons, with sir John of Wrotham, Doll his wench, and the Irishman in harpooles apparel.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: What intricate confusion have we here?
Not two hours since we apprehended one,
In habit Irish, but in speech, not so:
And now you bring another, that in speech
Is altogether Irish, but in habit
Seems to be English: yea and more than so,
The servant of that heretic lord Cobham.

sp.speaker: Irishman
sp.l: Fait me be no servant of the lord Cobham's,
Me be Mack Chane of Ulster.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Otherwise called Harpoole of Kent, go to sit,
You cannot blind us with your broken Irish.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.l: Trust me, my lord Bishop, whether Irish,
Or English, Harpoole or not Harpoole, that
I leave to be decided by the trial:
But sure I am this man by face and speech
Is he that murdered young sir Richard Lee:
I met him presently upon the fact,
And that he slew his master for that gold,
Those jewels, and that chain I took from him.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Well, our affairs do call us back to London,
So that we cannot prosecute the cause
As we desire to do, therefore we leave
The charge with you, to see they be conveyed
To Hartford Sise: both this counterfeit
And you sir John of Wrotham, and your wench,
For you are culpable as well as they,
Though not for murder, yet for felony.
But since you are the means to bring to light
This graceless murder, you shall bear with you,
Our letters to the judges of the bench,
To be your friends in what they lawful may.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: I thank your lordship.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: So, away with them.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter gaoler and his man, bringing forth old castle.

sp.speaker: Gaoler
sp.l: Bring forth the prisoners, see the court prepared,
The justices are coming to the bench.
So, let him stand, away, and fetch the rest.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: O give me patience to endure this scourge,
Thou that art fountain of that virtuous stream,
And though contempt, false witness, and reproach
Hang on these iron gyves, to press my life
As low as earth, yet strengthen me with faith,
That I may mount in spirit above the clouds.
sp.stage: Enter gaoler bringing in lady Oldcastle, and Harpoole.
sp.l: Here comes my lady, sorrow 'tis for her,
Thy wound is grievous, else I scoff at thee.
What and poor Harpoole! art thou ith' briars too?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: i'faith my lord, I am in, get out how I can.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Say (Gentle lord) for now we are alone,
And may confer, shall we confess in brief,
Of whence, and what we are, and so prevent
The accusation is commenced against us?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: What will that help us? being known, sweet love,
We shall for heresy be put to death,
For so they term the religion we profess.
No, if it be ordained we must die,
And at this instant, this our comfort be,
That of the guilt imposed, our souls are free.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Yea, yea my lord, Harpoole is so resolved,
I wreak of death the less, in that I die
Not by the sentence of that envious priest
The Bishop of Rochester, o were it he,
Or by his means that I should suffer here,
It would be double torment to my soul.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Well, be it then according as heaven please.

div.stage: Enter lord judge, two justices, mayor of saint Albons, lord Powesse and his lady, and old sir Richard Lee: the judge and justices take their places.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Now m. maior, what gentleman is that,
You bring with you, before us and the bench?

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.l: The lord Powes if it like your honour,
And this his lady, travelling towards Wales,
Who for they lodged last night within my house,
And my lord Bishop did lay search for such,
Were very willing to come on with me,
Lest for their sakes, suspicion we might wrong.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: We cry your honour mercy good my lord,
Wilt please ye take your place, madam your ladyship,
May here or where you will repose yourself,
Until this business now in hand be passed.

sp.speaker: Lady po.
sp.l: I will withdraw into some other room,
So that your lordship, and the rest be pleased.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.p: With all our hearts: attend the lady there.

sp.speaker: Lord po.
sp.l: Wife, I have eyed yond prisoners all this while,
And my conceit doth tell me, 'tis our friend,
The noble Cobham, and his virtuous lady.

sp.speaker: Lady po.
sp.l: I think no less, are they suspected trow ye
For doing of this murder?

sp.speaker: Lord po.
sp.l: What it means,
I cannot tell, but we shall know anon,
Mean space as you pass by them, ask the question,
But do it secretly, you be not seen,
And make some sign that I may know your mind.

sp.speaker: Lady po.
sp.p: My lord Cobham, madam?As she passeth over the stage by them.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: No Cobhan now, nor madam as you love us,
But John of Lancashire, and Joan his wife.

sp.speaker: Lady po.
sp.l: O tell, what is it that our love can do,
To pleasure you, for we are bound to you.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Nothing but this, that you conceal our names,
So gentle lady pass for being spied.

sp.speaker: Lady po.
sp.p: My heart I leave, to bear part of your grief.Exit,

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Call the prisoners to the bar: sir Richard Lee,
What evidence can you bring against these people,
To prove them guilty of the murder done?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: This bloody towel, and these naked knives,
Beside we found them sitting by the place,
Where the dead body lay within a bush.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: What answer you why law should not proceed,
According to this evidence given in,
To tax ye with the penalty of death?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: That we are free from murders very thought,
And know not how the gentleman was slain.

sp.speaker: 1 justice
sp.p: How came this linen cloth so boudy then?

sp.speaker: Lady Cob.
sp.l: My husband hot with travelling my lord,
His nose gushed out a bleeding, that was it.

sp.speaker: 2 justice
sp.p: But wherefore were your sharp edged knives unsheathed?

sp.speaker: Lady Cob.
sp.p: To cut such simple victual as we had.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Say we admit this answer to those articles,
What made ye in so private a dark nook,
So far remote from any common path,
As was the thick where the dead corpses was thrown?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Journeying my lord from London from the term,
Down into Lancashire where we do dwell,
And what with age and travel being faint,
We gladly sought a place where we might rest,
Free from resort of other passengers,
And so we strayed into that secret corner.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: These are but ambages to drive of time,
And linger justice from her purposed end.
But who are these?

div.stage: Enter the constable, bringing in the Irishman, sir John of Wrotham, and Doll

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Stay judgement, and release those innocents,
For here is he, whose hand hath done the deed,
For which they stand indicted at the bar,
This savage villain, this rude Irish slave,
His tongue already hath confessed the fact,
And here is witness to confirm as much.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.l: Yes my good lords, no sooner had he slain
His loving master for the wealth he had,
but I upon the instant met with him,
And what he purchased with the loss of blood,
With strokes I presently bereaved him of,
Some of the which is spent, the rest remaining,
I willingly surrender to the hands
Of old sir Richard Lee, as being his,
Beside my lord judge, I greet your honour,
With letters from my lord of Winchester.Delivers a letter.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: Is this the wolf whose thirsty throat did drink
My dear son's blood? art thou the snake
He cherished, yet with envious piercing sting,
Assailed'st him mortally? foul stigmatic,
Thou venom of the country where thou livd'st,
And pestilence of this: were it not that law
Stands ready to revenge thy cruelty,
Traitor to God, thy master, and to me,
These hands should be thy executioner.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Patience sir Richard Lee, you shall have justice,
And he the guerdon of his base desert,
The fact is odious, therefore take him hence,
And being hanged until the wretch be dead,
His body after shall be hanged in chains,
Near to the place, where he did act the murder.

sp.speaker: Irish.
sp.p: Prithee lord shudge let me have mine own clothes, my strouces there, and let me be hanged in a with after my country, the Irish fashion.Exit.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Go to, away with him, and now sir John,
Although by you, this murder came to light,
And therein you have well deserved, yet upright law,
So will not have you be excused and quit,
For you did rob the Irishman, by which
You stand attained here of felony,
Beside, you have been lewd, and many years
Led a lascivious unbeseeming life.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: O but my lord, he repents, sir John repents he will mend.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: In hope thereof, together with the favour,
My lord of Winchester entreats for you,
We are content you shall be proved.

sp.speaker: Sir John
sp.p: I thank your good lordship.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: These other falsely here, accused, and brought
In peril wrongfully, we in like sort
Do set at liberty, paying their fees.

sp.speaker: Lord po.
sp.l: That office if it please ye I will do,
For country's sake, because I know them well,
They are my neighbours, therefore of my cost,
Their charges shall be paid.

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: And for amends,
Touching the wrong unwittingly I have done,
There are a few crowns more for them to drink.Gives them a purse.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.l: Your kindness merits praise sir Richard Lee,
So let us hence.Exeunt all but lord Powesse and Oldcastle.

sp.speaker: Lord po.
sp.l: But Powesse still must stay,
There yet remains a part of that true love,
He owes his noble friend unsatisfied,
And unperformed which first of all doth bind me,
To gratulate your lordship's safe delivery,
And then entreat, that since unlooked for thus,
We here are met, your honour would vouchsafe,
To ride with me to Wales, where though my power,
(Though not to quittance those great benefits,
I have received of you) yet both my house,
My purse my servants, and what else I have,
Are all at your command, deny me not,
I know the Bishop's hate pursues ye so,
As there's no safety in abiding here.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: 'Tis true my lord, and God forgive him for it.

sp.speaker: Lord po.
sp.l: Then let us hence, you shall be straight provided
Of lusty geldings, and once entered Wales,
Well may the Bishop hunt, but spite his face,
He never more shall have the game in chase.Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
